data.Name: Martin Luther
data.Description: Leader of the reformation in Wittenberg. Was brought to the Diet of Worms to testify  before the Charles V. Was kidnapped by associates of Frederick the Wise and hidden in the castle Wartburg.

data.Name: Philip Melanchthon
data.Description: Professor at Wittenberg. Assumed leadership in the absence of Martin Luther.

data.Name: Nicolaus von Amsdorf
data.Description: A colleague of Luther's at the University of Wittenberg, accompained him to the Leipzig debate and the Diet of Worms.

data.Name: Johannes Agricola
data.Description: A colleague of Luther's at the University of Wittenberg. Would establish Protestant reforms in Frankfurt in 1525.

data.Name: George Spalatin
data.Description: Real name was Georg Burckhardt. Studied at Erfurt, was put into the service of Frederick III, acting as a middle man between the elector and Martin Luther's reformation.

data.Name: Nikolaus Gerbel
data.Title/Position: Doctor of Canon and Civil Law
data.Description: German Humanist, maintained a friendly correspondence with Luther, Erasmus, and Melanchthon.

data.Name: Johannes Egranus
data.Description: Studied at Leipzig. He held several preaching positions in East Germany and was a vocal supporter of Luther.

data.Name: Franz von Sickingen
data.Description: Rhineland Knight, had hoped that Luther would stay with him rather than face judgment at Worms.

data.Name: Wolfgang Capito
data.Title/Position: Doctor of Theology, Chancellor to the Archbishop
data.Description: Assisted Albrecht von Mainz, embraced the Reformation in 1524, enacting reform in Strassburg.

data.Name: Hans Luder
data.Description: Martin Luther's father.

data.Name: Albrecht von Mainz
data.Title/Position: Elector, Archbishop of Mainz, Archbishop of Magdeburg
data.Description: Luther's key adversary in the indulgence controversy.

data.Name: Johann Lange
data.Description: A student with Luther in Erfurt, he led the Erfurt Augustinians, introducing Lutheran reforms in 1520.

data.Name: Wenceslas Link
data.Title/Position: Doctor of Theology, vicar general of the Augustinians.
data.Description: Augustinian monk. Before replacing Staupitz as the vicar general of the Augustinians, he served as a professor of theology at Wittenberg.

data.Name: Frederick III
data.Description: Elector of Saxony, member of the Ernestine line of the Wettin family. Remained a loyal Catholic until is death in 1525; he preserved the life of Martin Luther, providing for his exile at the Wartburg.

data.Name: George of Saxony
data.Title/Position: Duke of Saxony, Margrave of Meissen
data.Description: Duke of Saxony, member the Albertine line of the Wettin Family, remained loyal to Rome.

data.Name: Charles V
data.Description: Holy Roman Emperor, resided over Luther's questioning at the Diet of Worms.

data.Name: Hartmuth von Cronberg
data.Description: Knight and noble of the Rhineland. Very supportive of Luther's cause.

data.Name: Joachim I (Nestor)
data.Description: Elector of Brandenburg, member of the Hohenzollern house.

data.Name: Matthew Lang von Wellenburg
data.Title/Position: Cardinal, Prince and Archbishop of Salzburg
data.Description: Prince and Archbishop of Salzburg and a Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church who Luther hoped would provide support for the reformation.

data.Name: Ferdinand I
data.Title/Position: Brother and Deputy to Holy Roman Emperor
data.Description: Member of the Hapsburg dynasty, younger brother to Charles V.

data.Name: Thomas Müntzer
data.Description: Radical reformer, would become a critic of Luther and leader in the Peasent Rebellion of 1525.

data.Name: Jacobus Latomus
data.Description: Opponent of Luther, taught at the University of Louvain.

data.Name: Christian Döring
data.Description: Prominent Wittenberg business man. Also known as

data.Name: Peter Lupin
data.Description: Professor of philosophy and theology at the University of Wittenberg. Also known as

data.Name: Francis Faber
data.Description: Renaissance figure in Silesia. Began study in 1520 at the University of Leipzig where he defended Luther's cause.

data.Name: Johannes Oecolampadius
data.Description: Swiss reformer and humanist. Introduced Protestant reforms in Basel, Switzerland.

data.Name: Ulrich von Hutten
data.Description: Imperial knight and humanist. Supporter of Luther and the reformation.

data.Name: Bartholomew Bernhardi
data.Description: Former President of the University of Wittenberg.

data.Name: Martin Bucer
data.Description: Former Dominican, renounced his monastic vows after interacting with Luther. Would introduce Protestant reform to Strasbourg.

data.Name: Thomas Cajetan
data.Title/Position: Cardinal, Master of the Order of Preachers
data.Description: Master of the Dominicans, he had interrogated Luther at the Diet of Augsburg.

data.Name: Johan Maier von Eck
data.Description: Professor at Ingolstadt, chief opponent of Luther.

data.Name: Jerome Emser
data.Description: Professor at Leipzig, chief opponent of Luther.

data.Name: Peter Swawe
data.Description: Student of Luther's at Wittenberg, preached Protestant reforms in Poland.

data.Name: Justus Jonas
data.Description: Pastor and professor in Wittenberg.

data.Name: Andreas Bodenstein von Karlstadt
data.Description: Professor at Wittenberg. During Luther's exile, he began enacting iconoclastic reforms in Wittenberg. Upon Luther's return, he was alienated from the Wittenberg leadership.

data.Name: Johann Grunenberg
data.Description: Printer in Wittenberg.

data.Name: Melchior Lotter
data.Description: Printer in Leipzig and Wittenberg. Much preferred by Luther over Grunenberg.

data.Name: Desiderius Erasmus
data.Description: Leader of the Northern Renaissance, interlocuter with Luther.

data.Name: Johann of Saxony
data.Title/Position: Duke, Heir presumptive Elector of Saxony
data.Description: Little brother to Frederick III, would assume the position of Elector in 1525.

data.Name: Hans von Berlepsch
data.Description: Proprietor of the Wartburg, kept Luther hidden after the Diet of Worms.

data.Name: Lucas Cranach the Elder
data.Description: Court painter of Frederick III, leading citizen of Wittenberg, close associate of Martin Luther.

data.Name: Haugold von Einsiedel
data.Description: Administrator for the court of Saxony

data.Name: John von Taubenheim
data.Description: Administrator for the Electoral household of Saxony.

data.Name: Otto Brunfels
data.Description: Theologian from Strassbourg, he considered joining Luther in Wittenberg in the early 1520s. Remained in Strassbourg, where he was a headmaster for the town school.

data.Name: Caspar Uringer
data.Description: Friend of Gerbel's in Strassburg.

data.Name: Luke Bathod
data.Description: Priest, teacher, and friend of Gerbel's in Strassburg

data.Name: Margaret Lindenmann Luder
data.Description: Mother of Martin Luther

data.Name: Johann Tetzel OP
data.Description: Dominican friar, hired by Albrecht of Mainz in the indulgence controversy. Criticized heavily by Martin Luther

data.Name: Johann von Staupitz OSA
data.Title/Position: Vicar General of the Augustinian Friars
data.Description: Vicar general of the Augustinian order, he had a profound impact on Martin Luther. Once taught at the University of Wittenberg.

data.Name: Andrew Kauxdorff
data.Description: Cathedral preacher in Magdeburg, forced out of the pulpit in 1521 by the Cardinal.

data.Name: Michael Kreuz
data.Description: Young priest in Saxony who became convicted that he could not, in good conscience, perform the mass.

data.Name: Jacobus Probst
data.Description: Young minister, educated at Wittenberg. Spread Protestant teachings to the Netherlands and Northern Germany.

data.Name: Thomas Blaurer
data.Description: Student at Wittenberg, accompanied Luther to the Diet at Worms.

data.Name: Huldrych Zwingli
data.Description: Swiss reformer in the city of Zurich.

data.Name: Heinrich Glarean
data.Description: Swiss humanist and musician. Lifelong friend of Desiderius Erasmus.

data.Name: Michael Hummelberg
data.Description: Preacher and teacher in Ravensburg, sympathetic to Zwingli and Luther before his death in 1527.

data.Name: Beatus Rhenanus
data.Description: German Humanist, a close associate of Desiderius Erasmus

data.Name: Johannes Reuchlin
data.Description: Leading figure in the German Renaissance, a pioneer in Christian Hebraism.

data.Name: Konrad Pellikan
data.Description: Former Priest who participated in reform efforts in Basel and Zurich.

data.Author: Martin Luther
data.Mentions: Albrecht von Mainz, Nicolaus von Amsdorf
